entries.name: Running the Adventure
entries: This section is intended only for the {@b Dungeon Master (DM)}. It contains the core framework, necessary resources, and the full background for the adventure.

entries.name: Overview
entries: {@b {@i Vaelithra - Into Raijinsho}} is a high-level one-shot designed for a party of four to six characters of {@b Level 9}. The adventure combines environmental survival, tense negotiation, and a climactic confrontation with a formidable Adult White Dragon, all while advancing a secret, divine meta-plot.

items: {@b Author/Universe:} Malvidra Twisted World
{@b World:} {@b Dewanegara}
{@b Focus:} {@b Survival} (Extreme Cold), {@b Exploration} (Labyrinthine Lair), and {@b High-Level Combat}.
{@b Timeline:} {@b 6th Sol'thara, Sylvryn Day, Year 35 A.S. (After Sundering)}.

entries.name: Required Materials
entries: To run this adventure, the DM will need access to the core Fifth Edition rulebooks for rules on extreme environments and general mechanics. {@b Note:} Custom stat blocks will be required for the corrupted minions and specialized {@b Dragon-Kin Soldiers}.

rows: Essential for all player abilities and rules mechanics.
Extreme Cold (p. 110), Creating Monster Stat Blocks, Treasure
Crucial for tracking the perpetual winter and balancing the homebrewed enemy challenges.
Adult White Dragon (CR 13) as a base, Reference Stat Blocks
Contains the core mechanics for the final boss and templates for building the corrupted minions.

entries.name: The Sundering War and Vaeil's Intervention
entries: The world of {@b Dewanegara} was once ravaged by the {@b Sundering War}, a prolonged conflict fought between the Gods and the Demons. {@b Vaeil}, the God of Time and Keeper of the Archives, stood apart, observing the destructive stalemate. Concerned that the war would end in a mutual catastrophe, Vaeil intervened, subtly manipulating the currents of time to create a decisive outcome: the Gods emerged as the victors, while the Demons were spared total annihilation.

This manipulation, however, was known to powerful entities on both sides. The Gods, intent on preserving {@b Vaeil's Rewritten Archives} to secure their victory, and the Demons, seeking to control the Archives to seize power, both coveted Vaeil's domain. To safeguard his work and the balance he created, {@b Vaeil shattered his own soul into twelve fragments, known as the Vaelithra}, scattering them across Dewanegara and sometimes even beyond time.

entries.name: The Vaelithra Fragments
entries: {@b These twelve Vaelithra fragments} have manifested in diverse forms—as items, locations, living beings, or even spirits attached to a host. They are key to Vaeil's eventual return and the final struggle for the Archives.

items: {@b The Koi Vaelithra (Fragment Two):} This fragment has taken the form of a shimmering, silvery {@b Koi Fish} and resides in an ancient, enchanted pool deep within {@b Raijinsho Island}. Its ancient magical nature keeps the pool warm and completely unaffected by the tremendous dragon chill. {@b This is the true objective of the guiding fragment, Renata.}

{@b The Human Vaelithra (Guiding Fragment):} The {@b Newspaper Girl} who approaches the party is a critical Vaelithra entity. She is tasked with appearing in sequential adventures to guide heroes to the locations of the other eleven fragments, paving the way for a larger, long-term campaign about Vaeil's return.

entries.name: Harann's Reign of Terror
entries: {@b Harann Nemmonis}, a cruel {@b Adult White Dragon}, has claimed Raijinsho Island as her territory. Her magical control over the environment is absolute, locking the island in a lethal perpetual winter.

items: {@b Dragon's Forces:} Harann's strength lies in utilizing the corpses of her failed enemies. Raiders who couldn't defeat her have been twisted into {@b Frost-Cursed Mariners}—mindless automatons that patrol the exterior. Her skilled forces consist of organized, fanatic {@b Dragon-Kin Soldiers} who guard the winding cave complex.

{@b {@i DM Guide for Stat Blocks:}} Use base {@b Zombie} or {@b Ghoul} stat blocks, but grant them {@b Resistance} to {@i Cold damage} and an ability to impose {@b Disadvantage} on a target's next saving throw after a successful melee attack.

entries.name: Adventure Outline
entries: The party is hired by Captain Thania Schmidt under the false pretense of gold, as she seeks to exploit the adventurers' power to claim the dragon's {@b conventional wealth (gold and gems)}. Unbeknownst to them and the Captain, their involvement fulfills a divine summons orchestrated by the {@b Human Vaelithra, Renata}, whose sole goal is to retrieve the {@b Koi Vaelithra}.

rows: Social Interaction and Roleplaying (Act 0). Negotiation, lore introduction, and the subtle influence of the Human Vaelithra.
Environmental Challenge. The 48-hour sea voyage, testing the party with Extreme Cold rules and high tension with the pirate crew.
Exploration and Combat. Navigating the frozen sea, battling the corrupted minions, exploring the icy caves, and the climactic encounter with Harann Nemmonis and the discovery of the Koi Vaelithra.

entries.name: Getting Started
entries: The adventure begins with the party established as capable adventurers, perhaps resting or resupplying, at the docks of {@b Thundrum Port} on the {@b 6th Sol'thara, Sylvryn Day}.
The DM should begin the session by reading or paraphrasing the opening description for {@b Chapter 1: The Hook at Thundrum Port}.

data.name: Chapter 1: The Hook at Thundrum Port

entries.name: The Unlikely Messenger
entries: The adventure begins with the party established at the docks.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The docks of {@b Thundrum Port} are a tempest of activity on this {@b Sylvryn Day}. The air is thick with the smells of drying salt, burning tar, and the sweat of laborers. Amidst the chaos of pirate and merchant vessels, a youthful, slightly built {@b sea urchin newspaper girl} makes her way directly toward you. Her clothes are common and slightly damp, and she clutches a small stack of papers under one arm. Her eyes are strikingly light—a cool, pale silver that seems to hold a wisdom far older than her apparent age—and she offers a concise, intense greeting.

entries.name: DM Information
entries: The {@b Sea Urchin Newspaper Girl} is the {@b Human Vaelithra} named {@b Renata} fragment. She was specifically hired by {@b Captain Thania Schmidt} but took the job only to orchestrate this meeting. Use {@b Scout} statistics but replace Shortbow proficiency with proficiency in {@b Persuasion} and {@b Insight}, and the ability to cast {@i Guidance} once per short rest.
Her primary goal is to ensure the party accepts the contract and sets sail.

items: {@b Dialogue Cue:} The Vaelithra is straightforward and professional about the job, but her enthusiasm for {@i this particular raid} is unnervingly high. If the party asks who pays her, she replies honestly, "Captain Thania Schmidt hired me to deliver a message to the strongest looking crew. I am just making sure I deliver it to the right people."

{@b The Divine Pitch:} Her message is simple but emphasizes the cosmic stakes she knows are hidden: "Captain Schmidt offers {@b $50\%$ of the magic items} from the White Dragon's lair. But that dragon is a world-changer. If anyone is going to face it, the fate of many people—maybe even the {@b balance of the Sundering} itself—{@b rests on people like you}."

{@b Subtle Influence:} If a player attempts an {@b Insight check (DC 18)}, they sense a strange, deep-seated urgency in her, as if the clock is ticking on a matter far grander than pirate gold. The DM may grant a point of {@b Inspiration} to any character who hesitates but decides to follow her lead, representing the Vaelithra's subtle push of fate.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the party agrees to hear the full offer, the Vaelithra nods and points toward the {@b Glowing Gate} a few docks over, but pauses to allow the party a chance to discuss.

entries.name: The Moment to Prepare (Act 0)
entries: The {@b Sea Urchin Newspaper Girl} has delivered her pitch and given the party directions to the {@i Glowing Gate}, but she pauses, leaving the final few feet of the journey to the players.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The sea urchin nods once, her strange silver eyes fixed on your group, and points toward a battered caravel, the {@b Glowing Gate}, a few docks down. "She's waiting. You should talk now before you approach." With that, she turns and darts back into the crowd, leaving you with the heavy knowledge of the dragon's challenge and the unsettling feeling that she knows far more than she let on. The time is yours to prepare before you commit to {@b Captain Thania Schmidt's} raid.

entries.name: DM Information
entries: This is the core roleplaying and bonding segment of the chapter. Encourage the players to discuss the extreme danger of facing an {@b Adult White Dragon (CR 13)} and the peculiar nature of the messenger. This is also the point where players can leverage their character's knowledge to uncover the deeper lore of {@b Dewanegara}.
Encourage players to make an Intelligence (History), Intelligence (Religion), or Wisdom (Survival) check to recall information about the world.

colLabels: Information Revealed (Share only ONE of these per successful check)
rows: The Sundering (35 A.S.) fractured the natural order of the world. Areas like Raijinsho Island, where the weather is magically fixed and unnatural, often become strongholds for powerful creatures, attracting greater dangers.

The Sundering was secretly ended by the God of Time, Vaeil, who manipulated the past. This act of rewriting the Archives made both the Gods and the Demons interested in controlling those fragments of time—the Vaelithra.

The god Vaeil shattered his soul into twelve Vaelithra fragments to prevent his work from being undone. To have encountered a Vaelithra means your path has intersected with a key event in the world's survival.

White Dragons are the most cruel and avaricious of the chromatics. Their magic makes their territory lethally cold, and the whispers around Raijinsho claim any injury sustained on the island tends to fester and heal slowly.

entries.name: Development
entries: The players should determine their strategy: how to approach the negotiation, who will speak, and what they will demand. Once the players signal they have finished their discussion, they move on to the ship and the next scene.

entries.name: The Pirate's Terms
entries: The {@b Sea Urchin Vaelithra} has done her part. Now the adventurers must commit to the contract with the pirate captain.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The {@b Glowing Gate} is a ship that has seen too much hard living. Its hull shows patched wood, and its rigging is frayed—a genuine pirate vessel, not a pleasure craft. Standing on the worn deck is {@b Captain Thania Schmidt}. She is a compact woman, dressed in rough leather and armed with two cutlasses belted across her waist. Her face is a map of scars and sun exposure, and her eyes, devoid of any empathy, are impatient. She nods curtly toward the dock, having seen the newspaper girl dart away, and gestures you aboard. "Don't waste my time. The offer is simple."

entries.name: DM Information
entries: {@b Captain Thania Schmidt} (use {@b Bandit Captain} statistics, with a high {@b Wisdom (Insight)} modifier of +4) is a ruthless, desperate pragmatist. {@b She is only motivated by conventional wealth (gold, gems, tradable goods)}, not arcane or magical artifacts. She views magic items as dangerous, unpredictable, or difficult to fence.

items: {@b Dialogue Cue:} Thania is brief and focused only on the raid logistics and payment.

{@b The Contract:} "It's a smash-and-grab on {@b Raijinsho Island}. My crew gets us to the safe drop-off point and secures the perimeter for the escape. Your job is the cave—{@b the Frost-Cursed Mariners, the Dragon-Kin Soldiers, the traps, and the final fight with Harann Nemmonis.}"

{@b Payment Terms (Crucial Motivation):} "The payment is {@i *$50\%$ of any }magic items{@i  or }unique artifacts{@i  you pull from that central lair*}. {@b We take the bulk of the gold, gems, and common valuables.} Those fancy magical trinkets are more trouble than they're worth to me, but you mercenaries seem to love them. {@b I want the coin.} That's the deal. Say yes or no. I sail at the next high tide."

{@b Negotiation:} Thania's terms are harsh, but fair for a pirate of her standing. Any {@b Charisma (Persuasion)} checks to increase the {@i magic item} share must beat her {@b Wisdom (Insight) DC 17}. If the party presses too hard for the gold share, she becomes hostile and might even draw a weapon, threatening to find a less greedy group.

entries.name: Failure and Lore (Revised)
entries: If the party attempts to deceive {@b Captain Thania} (and fail the necessary checks) or if they try to reject the contract outright, the {@b Human Vaelithra} (Newspaper Girl) will intercede to ensure the mission goes forward.

items: {@b Refusal:} If the party flatly refuses the mission, the Sea Urchin Vaelithra reappears instantly. She will not plead or beg. Instead, she will use her subtle divine influence and knowledge of time to change the circumstances.

{@b Vaelithra Intervention:} The Vaelithra looks directly at the most vocal character and, using the power of {@i Guidance}, suggests a single, crucial term that Thania might accept, such as guaranteeing that the party gets $50\%$ of the magic items {@b and} a guaranteed $5,000$ gold pieces payout upon return, regardless of the dragon's main gold pile.
She then quickly says, "She will agree to that. You must go," before vanishing again into the crowd.

Thania, startled by the Vaelithra's sudden return and demand, is momentarily unnerved. The DM should give the party {@b Advantage} on their next {@b Charisma (Persuasion)} check if they immediately counter with the Vaelithra's suggested term. Thania, realizing the messenger is more than she seems, will grudgingly accept the new term to rid herself of the unsettling girl.

entries.name: Departure Timeline
entries: If the party agrees, Thania directs them to her skeptical first mate, Kaelen, for basic supplies and a final word: "Good. We sail in {@b less than an hour}. Get your gear and get ready to freeze. I won't wait for latecomers."

data.name: Chapter 2: The Journey and the Cold
entries: This chapter covers the two-day, high-tension voyage to {@b Raijinsho Island}. It is designed to drain some of the party's resources (spells, hit dice) through environmental challenges and establish the mistrust between the adventurers and the pirate crew.

entries.name: Setting Sail
entries: The adventure immediately shifts from negotiation to preparation.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The docks of {@b Thundrum Port} fall away behind you as the {@b Glowing Gate} is quickly maneuvered out into the open water. The ship is sturdy, but loud—every timber groans as the vessel catches the wind. Captain Thania gives you a single, grim nod as the sun begins its slow descent. You have approximately {@b forty-eight hours} of travel ahead. With every league sailed, the air grows colder, and the sea becomes darker and more turbulent, building a palpable sense of dread as you head toward the magically frozen silhouette of {@b Raijinsho Island}.

entries.name: DM Information
entries: The journey takes 48 hours. The focus here should be on the relentless, creeping danger of the environment.

entries.name: The Chill of Nemmonis
entries: As the {@i Glowing Gate} nears the island, it enters the {@b Regional Effects} of the Adult White Dragon, {@b Harann Nemmonis}. The cold is unnaturally intense and punishing.

items: {@b The First Day (The Watch):} During the first 24 hours of the voyage, the air temperature drops drastically. All characters are considered to be in an area of {@b Cold Weather}. Characters who are not wearing {@b cold weather gear} or protected by magic suffer {@b Disadvantage} on {@b Ability Checks} that rely on {@b Dexterity}.
{@b The Second Day (Extreme Cold):} After the first 24 hours, the crew is sailing in an area of {@b Extreme Cold}.

{@b DM Rule:} Refer to the {@b Dungeon Master's Guide (DMG)}, {@i Chapter 5: Adventure Environments} for the rules on {@b Extreme Cold (p. 110)}. Characters must succeed on a {@b DC 10 Constitution saving throw} at the end of each hour or gain one level of {@b Exhaustion}. Those wearing cold weather gear or protected by magic automatically succeed. This resource drain is meant to make the initial landing on Raijinsho feel earned and desperate.

entries.name: First Contact (Foreshadowing Skirmish)
entries: On the second night, roughly 36 hours into the voyage, the {@i Glowing Gate} drifts close enough to the {@b frozen sea} to be noticed by the dragon's corrupted minions. This encounter provides the party with their first taste of Harann's army.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

You are deep into the second night. The ship is encased in a crust of frost, and the constant moan of the wind is broken by the creak of the hull fighting the waves. Suddenly, the lookout shouts a warning. In the gloom, figures are pulling themselves out of the frigid water onto the ship's railing—their skin is the color of old ice, and their movements are stiff, unnatural, driven by something other than life.

entries.name: DM Information
entries: Run this as a brief, desperate encounter.

items: {@b Enemies:} Deploy {@b two to three} of {@b Frost-Cursed Mariner}.

{@b Objective:} This is not a major combat, but a quick defense. The {@b Frost-Cursed Mariner} aim to kill or disable the closest living crew member, proving that the dragon's influence extends far out to sea.
{@b Tension:} Captain Thania (or her crew) will shout for the adventurers to handle the threat, focusing on protecting the ship's rigging and helm rather than engaging directly.

entries.name: Development
entries: The fight should be over quickly. Once the corrupted minions are defeated (and they do not surrender), their icy bodies shatter and dissolve back into the frigid sea.

items: {@b Lore Drop:} Captain Thania approaches afterward, clearly shaken. "Those are the damned fools who failed to raid her five years ago. Harann uses their corpses to guard her borders. Kill them quickly, or they'll turn you into one of them." This confirms the fate of failed raiders and reinforces the terrifying scope of the dragon's power.

entries.name: The Crew's Grudges
entries: The party is traveling with pirates who resent sharing the hard-won treasure with mercenaries. This provides roleplaying opportunities and tension.
{@b First Mate Kaelen} (use {@b Bandit} statistics with {@b Advantage} on Intimidation checks) is the most vocal opponent.)

items: {@b Roleplaying Note:} Kaelen is openly contemptuous. She believes the party will doom the ship and should not receive the share of magic items.
{@b Confrontation:} At some point during the journey, Kaelen confronts the party, likely at dinner or during a cold shift on deck. She accuses them of cowardice or greed.

{@b Options:} The party can respond with {@b Charisma (Intimidation)} or {@b Charisma (Persuasion)} (both {@b DC 15}) to shut her down or ease tensions. A failure results in Kaelen sulking and refusing to share information. A success sees Kaelen grudgingly respect the adventurers and share a final, key piece of local knowledge: "The {@b Dragon-Kin Soldiers} carry horns. If they blow them, the ice will {@i shift}."

entries.name: Development
entries: The 48 hours conclude as the {@i Glowing Gate} is forced to halt its progress. The water is no longer liquid, but a jagged, impossibly wide sheet of ancient, frozen sea.
The characters are now ready to disembark and face the final chapter.

data.name: Chapter 3: Into the Labyrinth of Ice
entries: This final chapter is split into two phases: the grueling trek across the frozen sea and shore, and the descent into the labyrinthine lair itself.

entries.name: Phase 1: The Frozen Approach
entries: This phase begins the moment the party disembarks and involves a long sequence of skill challenges and combat encounters across the vast, frozen landscape before they reach the relative safety of the main cave entrance.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The {@b Glowing Gate} groans to a halt. The sea ahead is no longer water, but a vast, terrifying expanse of ancient, jagged ice—the {@b frozen sea} that protects Raijinsho Island. The island itself is a mountain of blinding white, shrouded by thick, swirling clouds that whip snow across the deck. Captain Thania hands you a coil of rope and a grim look. "The ice is treacherous. The shore is a long walk, and the dragon's territory is everywhere. Good luck, mercenaries. We'll be waiting for your signal."

entries.name: The Treacherous Sea
entries: The distance from the ship to the island shore is roughly {@b half a mile} of frozen sea. The constant wind and ice ensure the {@b Extreme Cold} rules (DMG p. 110) remain in effect throughout this phase.

items: {@b Skill Challenge (Navigation):} To cross the frozen sea quickly and safely, the party must succeed on a series of skill checks. Require the party to collectively achieve {@b 6 successes} before accumulating 3 failures.

{@b Available Checks (DC 15):} {@b Wisdom (Survival)} to find stable paths; {@b Strength (Athletics)} to climb over high ice ridges; {@b Intelligence (Nature)} to predict thin ice; {@b Dexterity (Acrobatics)} to traverse slippery patches.

{@b Consequences of Failure:} If the party accumulates 3 failures, they fall into a hidden crevasse or trigger a patch of thin ice. They take {@b 2d6 bludgeoning damage} from the fall and must spend one round stabilizing before climbing out.

entries.name: Ambush: The Corrupted Patrol
entries: Midway across the frozen sea, the party is attacked by the dragon's mindless sentinels.

items: {@b Enemies:} {@b Three Frost-Cursed Mariners} and {@b One Frost-Cursed Captain}.

{@b The Dragon's Eye:} During the combat, the DM should briefly describe a shadow passing far overhead—a fleeting sign that {@b Harann Nemmonis} is aware of the intruders, though she is too arrogant to intervene personally at this distance.

entries.name: Frozen Corpse Loot Table
entries: After combat or during their exploration, players may search the bodies of the {@b Frost-Cursed Mariner} or other partially frozen corpses they spot in the ice. Roll on the table below to determine what grim scraps of previous expeditions they uncover.

rows: The corpse is stripped bare and frozen solid. You find nothing of value.
A single ration of frozen ship biscuits, still edible.
A handful of worthless, frozen coins fused into the corpse's belt.
A frozen, non-magical climbing pick. The metal is brittle and will likely snap if used in any demanding way.
A single, frozen page detailing a desperate final entry about "the horns" or "the whispers in the ice," warning about the Dragon-Kin Soldiers.
A small vial of strong Dwarven spirits that gives one character Advantage on their next DC 10 Constitution saving throw against Extreme Cold.
A polished, but chillingly cold quartz (worth 50 gp) clutched in the corpse's hand.
A water-damaged scroll that is still legible. It has the Protection from Energy spell (Cold only).

entries.name: The Snow-Covered Shore
entries: After successfully crossing the frozen sea, the party reaches the shore—a wide, flat beach now buried under deep, uneven snow.

items: {@b Environmental Challenge:} The deep snow makes movement difficult. Treat the entire shoreline as {@b difficult terrain}.
{@b Encounter:} Guarding the central entrance to the {@b Cave Labyrinth} are the Dragon's organized soldiers.

{@b Enemies:} {@b Two Frost-Cursed Kobold} and {@b Two Frost-Cursed Chieftain}. They utilize {@b Hit-and-Run} tactics, focusing on harassing the party and retreating into the caves if severely threatened, ready to ambush again inside.

entries.name: Phase 2: The Cave Labyrinth
entries: Once the party enters the main cave system, they begin the dungeon crawl toward the final lair. The labyrinth is a maze of slick, ice-covered tunnels and larger chambers that once served a community living beneath the island's volcanic core—now silent and frozen.

entries.name: Environmental Hazard: The Whisper of Ice

items: {@b Difficult Terrain:} Treat all non-chamber areas as {@b difficult terrain} due to the slick ice.
{@b Slippery Surfaces:} Any time a character moves more than half their speed, they must succeed on a {@b DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check} or fall prone.
{@b Illusory Frost:} Treat all areas beyond 60 feet as {@b lightly obscured}.

entries.name: Frozen Treasures and the Failed Raid
The Frozen Chest
entries: In a medium-sized tunnel junction, the party discovers a chest fused into a sheet of ice.

items: {@b Challenge:} The chest is covered in {@b 2 inches of solid ice}. Characters must spend time or resources to free it. Requires {@b 10 minutes} of sustained effort (and four successful {@b DC 15 Strength (Athletics)} checks) to free the chest.
{@b Loot:} The chest holds a minor reward: {@b 500 gp} worth of mixed, frozen currency and {@b two Potions of Greater Healing}.

entries.name: The Old Denizens: The Geothermal Locks (Puzzle)
entries: The winding tunnels occasionally reveal ancient, carved stone that predates the dragon, hinting at a former sanctuary. This can be solved to gain a tactical advantage or a minor reward.

entries.name: Puzzle: The Warm Path
entries: In a large central chamber, three paths lead deeper into the labyrinth. Two are choked with ice; the third is clear but marked by an ominous dragon claw scratch (Path C, the direct way to Harann).

items: {@b The Problem:} The two ice-choked paths (A and B) lead to a hidden stash or a bypass. The paths are sealed by a mechanical lock hidden on a carving of a great, coiled serpent (the denizens' original protector). A successful {@b DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation)} check reveals faint glyphs under the ice-slick, suggesting the path was once warmed by geothermal heat.

{@b The Solution:} A successful {@b DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana or Investigation)} check allows a character to activate the {@b Geothermal Lock} (a pressure/lever puzzle related to the serpent's scales). This action melts the ice from one of the choked paths (DM's choice: {@b Path A} leads to minor treasure; {@b Path B} leads to a direct, trap-free route to the lair).

entries.name: Guard Patrol: Dragon-Kin Ambush
entries: In a long, straight tunnel that shows signs of recent, meticulous cleanup, the Dragon-Kin Soldiers have set a defensive line.

items: {@b Enemies:} {@b Two Frost-Cursed Kobold} and {@b One Frost-Cursed Ogre} (homebrewed cold-resistant fighters).

{@b Traps:} The soldiers have rigged a tripwire connected to a chute that releases a torrent of {@b sharp, icy shards} (a homebrew hazard, dealing {@b 3d6 piercing damage} on a failed {@b DC 14 Dexterity saving throw}). The Dragon-Kin are positioned behind ice barriers, giving them {@b three-quarters cover} from the party.
{@b Loot:} A defeated Dragon-Kin may drop a {@b Dragon-Kin Warhorn}, which the party can use (see development later).

entries.name: The Dragon's Lair Entrance
entries: The final path (likely Path C or the successful Path B) leads to a massive, cavernous entrance, reeking of ozone, death, and frozen fish.

items: {@b Final Encounter:} The party has reached the main lair of {@b Harann Nemmonis}.

entries.name: The True Objective: The Koi Vaelithra (Post-Harann)
entries: {@b {@i (DM Note: This location is the true objective of the guiding Vaelithra fragment, Renata. It is not found until after the dragon is defeated or forced to flee.)}}
Located in a small, hidden tunnel leading from behind the dragon's main treasure room, the party discovers a simple sheet of ice sealing a doorway.

items: {@b Discovery:} A character who succeeds on a {@b DC 17 Wisdom (Perception)} or {@b Intelligence (Investigation)} check notices that this sheet of ice bears no dragon claw marks, and the ice looks thin—as if the dragon was never aware of its seam. {@b Renata may have subtly provided a clue near the main lair entrance (e.g., a faint, stylized Koi symbol scratched into the ground).}

{@b The Pond:} The tunnel opens up into a small, naturally warm chamber (a comfortable 50°F / 10°C). In the center is a small, crystal-clear pool fed by a hidden geothermal source. Floating within the pool is the shimmering, silvery {@b Koi Vaelithra}. The Koi's divine essence is palpable, offering a moment of quiet peace amidst the ruin.

{@b The Reward:} The {@b Koi Vaelithra} will make a single, clear mental contact with the nearest character, transmitting vital, cryptic information about the next Vaelithra fragment, essentially providing the hook for the next adventure in the campaign. The party can then collect the {@b magic items} from Harann's main hoard, fulfilling their contract with Captain Thania.

data.name: Epilogue
entries: This section concludes the adventure and provides a bridge to the next part of the {@b Malvidra Twisted World} narrative.

entries.name: The Retreat
entries: Whether {@b Harann Nemmonis} was slain, or simply dealt enough damage to retreat into her deeper lair, the outcome is the same: The magical field of perpetual winter over Raijinsho Island immediately begins to fail.

The party now has time to successfully harvest the agreed-upon $50\%$ share of the {@b magic items and unique artifacts} from the dragon's main hoard, fulfilling their contract with {@b Captain Thania Schmidt}.
The party then signals the {@i Glowing Gate}, which quickly approaches the rapidly melting shore to collect the adventurers.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

The moment the dragon's power breaks, the entire island sighs. The magical, unnatural cold lifts, causing frozen waterfalls to cascade down the cliffs and thick layers of rime to fall from the rigging of the {@i Glowing Gate}. The sky is suddenly clear, and birds circle overhead, filling the air with sound and color long absent from Raijinsho. {@b Captain Thania Schmidt} keeps her word, nodding stiffly as her crew confirms the magical haul. They set sail immediately, singing shanties of victory and treasure.

entries.name: The Guiding Fragment
entries: As the adventurers prepare to leave the island, the {@b Human Vaelithra}—who somehow managed to make the journey and return—approaches the party one last time, away from the celebration of the pirates.
{@b Read-Aloud Text:}

You find the {@b Human Vaelithra}—still disguised as the sea urchin newspaper girl—standing quietly near the newly thawed beach. Her small hands clutch the leather notebook she always carries, and her eyes shimmer with pride and something deeper, older, now that the immediate danger is past. She offers a small, knowing smile.
She then delivers her final, cryptic message:
{@b Human Vaelithra:} "The shard is safe again. One out of ten—"
She freezes mid-sentence, her eyes widening ever so slightly. Then she forces a laugh, correcting herself quickly:
{@b Human Vaelithra:} "Eleven. One out of eleven remain. Forgive me. Sometimes... I lose count."

An odd stillness follows the correction, like the sea itself is listening. If the party asks her what she means, she will dodge the question with a childlike grin, but her mask falters—just for a moment.
As she turns and walks toward the horizon, she adds quietly, almost to herself:
{@b Human Vaelithra:} "When the last is found, I will finally... come back."

The adventurers are left with gold, glory, and questions that echo louder than any dragon's roar. The sails of the {@i Glowing Gate} rise once more, catching a warm, welcoming wind. But the players now know their journey for coin has evolved into a vital quest for the survival of {@b Dewanegara}.

data.name: Introduction
entries: This one-shot is part of a larger narrative within the Malvidra Twisted World universe. It takes place in the final moments of Umbralos, the Month of Lengthening Shadows, and the beginning of Aetheros, the Month of Embers and Remembrance. The corruption of the Silver Light temple has plunged the city into chaos, a reflection of the troubled times.

entries.name: Running This Adventure
entries: The Ruin of Silver Light is a one-shot adventure for characters of 3rd level. It draws them into the heart of Dewanginokori, a city once blessed by divine favor and now tainted by corruption.

The story begins simply—with strangers forced together by a storm in the Boar Smile Tavern on the night of Vael'thra, the first day of the month. Soon, they discover whispers of disappearances, false blessings, and a holy order turned sinister.
The adventurers will:

items: Explore the uneasy city of Dewanginokori on Aethelos, Day 1.
Uncover the truth behind the Silver Light cult and its High Priest.
Descend into the ruins of the Silver Light temple.
Confront the cult's monstrous patron's pet, twisted by abyssal power.

entries: The climax brings them face-to-face with a fragment of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s will—the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}—and briefly with the abyssal master behind the corruption. Though the adventurers cannot fight this Archdemon, {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}, they witness how fragile time itself can be when gods and demons pull at its threads.

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: For centuries, the Silver Light order served as acolytes of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}, God of Time and Keeper of the Archive. In the city of Dewanginokori, they were beloved for their blessings—prayers over crops, safe births, successful trade, and guidance in life's trials.

Recently, however, a group of Drow elves arrived claiming devotion to {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}. In truth, they were secret worshipers of {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW} and sacrifice. Slowly, they wormed their way into the Silver Light, twisting its rituals and climbing its ranks. By the dark month of Umbralos, when the shadows lengthen, one of them was raised to High Priest. The order's blessings became bargains. Those who sought help were promised deliverance—then lured into the old temple of the Silver Light, now a ruin. There, the faithful were sacrificed to feed a horrific abyssal creature, the Archdemon's Pet, {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}.

Unseen, a fragment of {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s sundered soul walks the city as a beggar woman. This {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra} cannot act directly but watches for mortals brave enough to intervene. When the adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori during a torrential storm, on Aetheros, Day 1, fate gathers them together at the Boar Smile Tavern—their meeting place and the start of their journey into the shadows of the Silver Light.

entries.name: Adventure Outline
entries: This one-shot has three main chapters and one epilogue. Each brings the adventurers deeper into the corruption of the Silver Light:

items: {@b Chapter 1 - Boar Smile Tavern}: The adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori on the stormy evening of Aetheros, Day 1. With the tavern full, they are forced together at the bar itself, strangers sharing space. They soon hear rumors: families whispering about loved ones gone missing, blessings from the Silver Light turning hollow, and a beggar woman muttering of "light turned black." This chapter bonds the party and sets the hook to investigate the Silver Light's fall.

{@b Chapter 2 - The Silver Forest}: Following clues leads the adventurers into the Silver Forest, the sacred woods once tended by the Silver Light. Once bright with moonlit leaves and glimmering streams, it is now scarred—its wildlife restless, shadows moving where they shouldn't. Here, the adventurers face skirmishes with corrupted acolytes and glimpse signs of a greater darkness. They may meet the beggar woman again, who hints at the truth: "Not all who bless serve the Keeper of Time." The adventure continues on the same or next day

{@b Chapter 3 - The Ruin of Silver Light}: The adventurers reach the ruined temple of the Silver Light. Here they discover the cult's High Priest and their terrible secret: supplicants lured to sacrifice, their lifeblood feeding the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet. This becomes the adventure's climactic battle. If victorious, the adventurers free the captives and break the cult's hold—but their victory awakens something far worse.

{@b Epilogue - The Abyss Unveiled}: As the High Priest falls and {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS} is slain, the temple trembles. A rift tears open, and the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW} manifests in his true abyssal form—Gargantuan, overwhelming, a being no mortal could stand against. Just as despair takes hold, the sky shatters into blinding light. Time cracks. Reality folds back.

entries: The adventurers find themselves once more at the Boar Smile Tavern, the storm still raging outside, as if no time has passed. The date is Aetheros, Day 1 once again—but now the Silver Light is whole again, their order loyal to {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW} once more. Only the beggar woman's gaze lingers, knowing the truth: history was rewritten by the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}.

data.name: Chapter 1: The Boar Smile Tavern
entries: The adventure begins as the adventurers arrive in Dewanginokori under a torrential storm. Seeking warmth and shelter, they enter the Boar Smile Tavern, a bustling establishment packed full of travelers, locals, and laborers all waiting out the weather. With no empty tables left, the characters are forced to sit side by side at the bar, strangers drawn together by chance—or perhaps fate.
It's Year 1 After Sundering, on the 1st of Aetheros, the village of Dewanginokori was silent as expected

The rain pours heavily outside as thunder rattles the windows of the Boar Smile Tavern. Every table is full, leaving you no choice but to share one with strangers. The warmth of the hearth can't quite chase away the chill in the air, nor the uneasy whispers of the locals.

A group of Silver Light acolytes sit near the bar, their silver-embroidered robes darkened with damp. Once revered as the city's blessing-givers, now they mutter among themselves, avoiding the gaze of common folk. A farmer leans in to whisper:
"They don't bless the crops anymore. Those who beg their help vanish into the forest... and never come back."

entries.name: Roleplaying the Scene
entries: Encourage the players to introduce their characters: their weariness from travel, their reasons for being in Dewanginokori, and their reactions to being squeezed together. While they do, snippets of hushed conversation drift from the other customers. These whispers are the first hints that something is deeply wrong in the city.

entries.name: The Bartender
entries: The bartender on duty was an Elf named {@creature Demolias Nogard|MTW-VS}. With slightly disheveled blond hair and a pair of friendly green eyes, he greeted every newcomer with a warm smile. His build was unassuming, but his attire suggested a readiness for action: a white shirt and black vest paired with brown pants rolled up at the ankles. Your eye might be drawn to the sheathed shortsword on his back, a clear sign that he was more than just a man pouring drinks.

entries.caption: Menu List
rows: Bulette broth with chopped carrots served with a sliver of cow cheese
Brown bear broth with diced snap peas served with a wheat roll
Poached pufferfish served with raw snap peas and beets and a slice of cheddar cheese
Seared striped bass served with grilled snow peas and a slab of applewood cheese
Deboned kingfish sauteed in a salty cashew sauce served with a wedge of wheat bread
Boiled rock bass bisque with marinated turnips and pumpkin

entries.name: The Server
entries: The only server on duty was a woman with a commanding presence. Her name was {@creature Diane Serpent|MTW-VS}. She was notably tall with a strong, athletic build, and her brown hair was braided into two thick pigtails that swung slightly as she shifted her weight. Her uniform consisted of a tough, sleeveless gambeson over a loose-fitting tunic, and practical boots. The centerpiece of her gear, however, was a large, two-handed hammer that leaned against the wall next to her. She didn't seem to be in a rush, a silent guardian of the peace, ready to spring into action if needed.

entries.name: Rumors of the Silver Light
entries: As your party settles into town, you can hear whispers about the local temple, the Silver Light. If you listen closely, or ask around, you might uncover some unsettling truths.

entries.name: A Missing Boy
entries: You can try to catch the eye of a nervous-looking villager or simply listen in on a hushed conversation at the tavern.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 12} {@skill Perception} or {@skill Insight} check.

{@b Success}: You overhear a man talking to a friend, his voice filled with worry. 'My son, Thomas, went into the Silver Forest days ago. They told me the Silver Light would watch over him, but he hasn't come back. I fear... I fear he's gone.'

{@b Failure}: You only catch bits and pieces of the conversation. You hear the words 'missing' and 'Silver Forest', but you can't piece together the full story. The man's distress is clear, but the details are a blur.

entries.name: A Broken Worker
entries: A local woodcutter, his clothes tattered and face pale, stumbles into the tavern, shaking and unable to speak. His eyes dart around the room in a panicked daze.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 14} {@skill Insight} or {@skill Investigation} check to try and figure out what happened to him.

{@b Success}: You manage to get his attention and, with some gentle prompting, you learn he witnessed something terrible in the woods. He doesn't say what, but a single, terrifying word escapes his lips: 'They... changed.' He then collapses, exhausted.
{@b Failure}: The man is too traumatized to respond. All you can discern is a deep, paralyzing fear. He stares blankly at the wall, unable to communicate his experience.

entries.name: A False Blessing
entries: You hear whispers about a woman who rarely leaves her home anymore. It's said she had dealings with the Silver Light, but her story is a sad one. Finding her and convincing her to talk won't be easy.

items: {@b Skill Check}: Make a {@dc 15} {@skill Persuasion} or {@skill Intimidation} check to get her to open up.

{@b Success}: The woman, her eyes red from crying, tells you a sorrowful tale. Her brother was sick, and the Silver Light promised a cure if he came into their care. He vanished soon after, and she hasn't seen him since. She whispers, 'It wasn't a blessing. It was a lie.'
{@b Failure}: She becomes frightened and pulls away, refusing to speak of her brother. Her distress is obvious, but you can't get her to reveal why she's so afraid.

entries: These rumors paint a picture of unease and lost faith, setting suspicion on the Silver Light.

entries.name: A Call for Help
entries: The rain continues to fall in a heavy curtain outside, a steady drumming on the tavern roof. The world inside is warm and filled with the low murmur of conversation and the clinking of mugs.

Suddenly, the heavy oak door bursts open, and a gust of cold, wet air rushes in, along with a man drenched to the bone. His eyes are wide with panic and his face is streaked with rain and tears. The sound of his desperate scramble into the room, followed by his raw scream, is what shatters the quiet, forcing every conversation to an abrupt halt.
'Please!' he cries, his voice thick with terror. 'My sister—Elara! They took her!'

He clutches his chest before forcing himself to stand tall. 'They wore long gray robes, and they dragged her into the Silver Forest toward the old temple! My name is Gareth Blackwood, and I'll give you everything I have—my family's entire inheritance! Just please, bring my sister Elara Blackwood home!'

His desperate plea echoes through the sudden silence of the tavern. Every eye in the room—from the gruff dwarven merchant to the wary-looking barmaid—turns toward the man, and then to you. The weight of his hope and fear rests squarely on your shoulders.

entries.name: Into the Storm

entries: The tension from Gareth's plea dissipates as he leads you out of the tavern and into the unforgiving storm. The town's meager lights disappear behind you as you approach the dark, foreboding edge of the Silver Forest.
Here, at the treeline, Gareth stops. He turns to you, his face pale and eyes wide with terror, even more so than before.

'I can't... I can't go in there,' he stammers, pointing a shaking hand into the shadowy trees. 'I... I can't lose her again. But please, adventurers, I beg of you. Don't let them take her light forever.'
With that, he turns and flees back toward the safety of the town, leaving you alone at the mouth of the dark forest.

As the party enters the woods, two robed figures rise from the shadows of the tavern and begin to follow from a distance. These are members of the corrupted Silver Light, sent to monitor or eliminate anyone who interferes with their plans. They should remain unseen for now.

A beggar woman, huddled outside the tavern, watches the adventurers leave. This is {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, a fragment of the god Vaeil. She is observing the party's first steps on their journey, but she will not interfere. Her presence is a subtle hint of a larger, divine conflict.

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: This chapter shifts the adventure's tone entirely, moving from the safety of the tavern to the hostile tension of the woods. The Silver Forest is the players' first real taste of the corruption they are investigating, a place of twisted beauty that conceals a very real menace. This serves as a vital combat trial, meant to test your party's cohesion and combat strategy.

Encourage your players to explore the unsettling signs of corruption in the forest before the ambush. These clues are designed to build dread and foreshadow that something ancient and unnatural—the {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet—lingers deeper within.

entries.name: Entering the Forest
entries: As the adventurers step beneath the forest canopy, they are met by an eerie, sudden stillness. The air grows heavy, muffling their footsteps and the patter of the rain, as if they've walked into a vacuum. The ancient trees and stones here are scarred with deep, jagged gashes, as though claws or blades have carved at the land itself. Strange silver motes drift through the branches, shimmering faintly before dissolving into nothingness when touched. Every now and then, a faint whisper—like a distorted prayer—echoes through the silence, carried on a non-existent breeze.

(Optional: A successful {@dc 15} {@skill Survival} or {@skill Arcana} check reveals that these marks are not random, but part of a sinister ritual, a deliberate defiling of the forest's natural life.)

entries.name: The Ambush at the Halfway Point
entries: Just as the party nears the halfway point to the temple ruins, five figures melt from the shadows of the forest. They block the path ahead, their silver robes and gaunt faces a chilling mirror of the order they profess to serve.

items: 4 {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}.
1 {@creature Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}.

entries: Their goal is not to kill but to capture—they believe the adventurers are fated sacrifices or useful tools for their cause. The priest's eyes glow with a fanatic's devotion as he gestures, commanding his acolytes. "Chosen offerings," he declares, his voice a low hiss, "you walk willingly into our master's grace!"

items: The acolytes and priest fight fiercely but with a reckless abandon. They prefer non-lethal strikes (such as the flats of their blades or blows to the head) to subdue the party, though their fanaticism may lead to lethal force if they are cornered. This combat will serve as a hard test of the party's skills.
After a few rounds, the priest may use a spell to try and disorient the party, attempting to give the acolytes an advantage.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: If the party is defeated, they will awaken bound and unconscious at the entrance to the ruins, starting Chapter 3 at a disadvantage. If the party wins, the priest is left critically wounded and can be interrogated.

items: With a successful {@dc 15} {@skill Persuasion} or {@skill Intimidation} check, the priest, in his dying breaths, reveals:
A clear path to the Ruin of Silver Light, a twisted stairway covered in thorny vines.
A dark hint that the cult seeks to 'awaken their chained master'— {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}'s Pet.
A final, chilling warning: "You think you walk toward salvation... but you walk willingly into the maw of eternity."

entries: With the ambush resolved, the adventurers can now find the overgrown stairway that marks the temple entrance, where this chapter ends. The darkness of the forest gives way to the true corruption of the ruins.
Use the table bellow for player if they looting:

data.name: Chapter 3: The Ruin of Silver Light

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: This is the climax of the adventure, where the party faces the source of the city's corruption. This chapter is designed as a two-phase combat encounter, escalating from a standard battle against the cult leaders to a full-blown boss fight. The transition should be dramatic, triggered by the players' success in the first phase. The final intervention by the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra} serves as a narrative device to prevent a Total Party Kill, making the encounter cinematic and allowing the story to flow into the epilogue.

entries.name: The Temple Gate
entries: After navigating the corrupted forest, the adventurers arrive at what was once the grand entrance to the temple of the Silver Light. The gate stands as a grim silhouette against the stormy sky, its intricate carvings of Vaeil and his celestial Archives now defaced and covered in abyssal glyphs. The air here is cold and heavy with the scent of decay. A low, guttural chanting echoes from within the ruins, a foul perversion of the order's old prayers. The path leads to a shattered, overgrown stairway that descends into darkness.

entries.name: The High Priest's Stand
entries: As the adventurers descend into the main hall of the temple, the chanting stops. Five figures stand before a jagged rift in reality, their silver robes stained with blood and filth. In the center, the High Priest, a Drow Elf, turns to face them, his eyes glowing with black light. He is flanked by two robed Priests and three hooded Acolytes, who clutch their daggers with zealous fervor. The High Priest raises his hands, his voice echoing with a cruel mockery of Vaeil's blessing. "You have intruded on the most sacred of rituals," he hisses. "You are not a sacrifice... you are simply a feast!"

items: The encounter is with the following creatures:
1 {@creature High Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
2 {@creature Priest of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
3 {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}
The High Priest will prioritize using spells to weaken and control the party, while the acolytes attack recklessly to wear them down.
The goal of the cultists is to incapacitate the adventurers for sacrifice, but they will not hold back on lethal force if the party proves too resilient.

entries: The battle is a tense, desperate struggle. The moment the High Priest's hit points are reduced to 50% or less, or when half of his accompanying forces have been defeated, the ground trembles and the final phase of the battle begins.

entries.name: The Abyssal Maw
entries: The rift behind the High Priest tears open with a deafening screech of rending metal. The abyssal chanting swells into a roar as the true lord of these ruins emerges: {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}. A gargantuan, multi-limbed creature of nightmare, it is a fleshy, chitinous horror with an impossibly wide maw filled with rows of razor-sharp teeth. Its body seems to warp and pull at the space around it, its movements erratic and alien. It has been a long time since its master fed it so well, and it is hungry for more.

entries.name: The Light of Vaeil
entries: If the party is defeated or clearly losing the battle against the {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}, a blinding light erupts from the sky, a single, brilliant ray that shatters the temple's ceiling. This is the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}'s power, a desperate act to correct a timeline that has gone too far. The light strikes the Maw, scorching it and instantly incinerating any remaining cultists. The Maw's body convulses, and it is left with only 20% of its total hit points remaining. The air shimmers with temporal energy, and for a fleeting moment, the adventurers catch a glimpse of the beggar woman from the tavern, her eyes glowing with impossible power, before the scene resets.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: Whether by their own hand or by the grace of the {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, the adventurers defeat the {@creature The Abyssal Maw|MTW-VS}. As the monstrosity's body dissolves, a final, guttural scream tears from the rift in reality. The archdemon manifests in his true, gargantuan form—an overwhelming being of pure abyss and despair. This is where the adventure's epilogue begins.
A {@item Fragment of the Archive|MTW-VS} is laying beside the High Priest and can be taken.

data.name: Epilogue

entries.name: The Boar Smile Tavern Revisited
entries: The rain pours heavily outside as thunder rattles the windows of the Boar Smile Tavern. Every table is full, leaving you no choice but to share one with strangers. The warmth of the hearth fills the room, carrying the sound of laughter and song.

A group of Silver Light acolytes sit near the bar, their silver-embroidered robes bright in the firelight. They raise cups with locals, blessing farmers and cradling newborns offered into their arms. A villager smiles at you warmly and whispers:
The Silver Light keeps us safe. {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}'s blessings shine upon Dewanginokori once more.
A figure in hooded white robe approaches the bar you guys were sitting, after ordering a mead from Demolias they turn at you and put off the hood of their robe.
A woman with golden hair, her eyes is shining from the light reflection with a silver hue. She wave and greeted you
'Hello, my name is {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}'
And there's where our adventure would end.

Though the adventurers recall the horrors faced within the Silver Forest, none around them seem to bear such memories. Time has been rewritten by {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}, fragment of Vaeil, restoring Dewanginokori to its golden age.

The loop closes where it began—the Boar Smile Tavern, the rain, the strangers at a crowded table—but now the weight of destiny hangs heavy. For the Archive remains threatened, and this was but the first page of a greater tale.

data.name: Vaeil
data.symbol: A serene, all-seeing eye within a perfect clock, surrounded by the Ouroboros.
entries: {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is the benevolent deity who brought order from primordial chaos and established the flow of time. He is the guardian of the timeline, ensuring that the grand design of the cosmos unfolds as it should.

While {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is often seen as a distant and impassive force, his influence is felt in the cycles of the seasons, the turning of the stars, and the natural progression of life and death. His followers, such as the {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}, strive to maintain order, preserve knowledge, and protect the world from the disruptive influence of chaotic forces.

{@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}'s power is not one of direct intervention, but of subtle guidance and correction. He acts through his devoted followers to restore balance and mend the tears in the fabric of reality caused by beings like {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}. His greatest triumph was the ending of the {@adventure War of Sundering|MTW|war-of-sundering}, which he accomplished by resetting time, an act that fractured a part of his soul, creating the entity known as {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}.

data.name: Vaeil, The God of Time
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Vaeil makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Chronal Shift (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Vaeil can reroll a saving throw it just failed. It must use the new roll. This can be used to counter an effect that would reduce its Legendary Resistance.

legendary.name: Divine Strike (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Vaeil makes one melee weapon attack. On a hit, the target takes an additional 27 ({@damage 5d10}) radiant damage.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Vaeil's spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 26}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
At will: {@spell command}, {@spell time ravage|MTW}
3/day each: {@spell banishment}, {@spell divine word}
1/day each: {@spell foresight}, {@spell prismatic wall}

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (5/Day)
entries: If Vaeil fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Time Reversal
entries: If Vaeil would be reduced to 0 hit points, his current hit point total instead resets to 400 hit points, he recharges all his abilities, and he regains any expended uses of Legendary Resistance.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Vaeil makes two melee attacks with its radiant fists.

action.name: Radiant Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: 15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Temporal Warp
entries: Vaeil chooses a point within 120 feet of him. A 30-foot-radius sphere centered on that point becomes a zone of temporal distortion until the start of his next turn. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature's speed is halved, and it can't take reactions. On a successful save, the creature's speed is halved. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

data.name: Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks

trait.name: Change Shape
entries: Vaelithra can use her action to polymorph into a Medium humanoid she has seen, or back into her true form. Her statistics, other than her size, are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.

In her humanoid form, she appears as a striking but unassuming human woman with silver-streaked hair and eyes that occasionally flicker with an inner light. This form is her preferred way to interact with mortals, as it helps her remain inconspicuous while still maintaining an air of otherworldly grace.

trait.name: Fragmented Divinity
entries: As a shard of Vaeil, Vaelithra wields divine power but cannot fully control it. Whenever she rolls a natural 1 on an attack roll, saving throw, or ability check, time shatters momentarily. Each creature within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Vaelithra's spellcasting ability is Charisma spell save {@dc 21}. She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
At will: {@spell hold person}, {@spell slow}, {@spell counterspell}
3/day each: {@spell banishment}, {@spell greater restoration}, {@spell wall of force}
1/day each: {@spell time stop}, {@spell foresight}

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Vaelithra fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Vaelithra makes two attacks with her Chronal Strike.

action.name: Chronal Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) force damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage. On a hit, the target must succeed on a DC 21 Wisdom saving throw or lose its reaction until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Temporal Distortion
entries: Vaelithra bends the flow of time in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point she can see within 120 feet. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 21 Wisdom saving throw or be either aged (disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws) or slowed (as the {@spell slow} spell) for 1 minute. The effect ends early if Vaelithra loses concentration (as if concentrating on a spell).

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Vaelithra makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Warp Step
entries: Vaelithra teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space she can see.

legendary.name: Chronal Glimpse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Vaelithra forces a creature she can see within 30 feet to reroll an attack roll, saving throw, or ability check it just made. The creature must use the new roll.

data.name: Xy'loth
data.symbol: A stylized serpent intertwined with a shattered clock, its head poised to strike the center.
entries: {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the primordial chaos that exists outside of time. It is not a being of flesh and blood but a malevolent force that seeks to unravel the orderly fabric of the multiverse, which was woven by {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}.

Unlike other demons who seek power or conquest, {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}'s sole purpose is the ultimate unmaking of all things, returning them to the chaotic void from which it came. Its influence is insidious, working through whispers and subversion rather than brute force.

{@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the master of lies, twisting the faith of mortals, and turning order against itself. The {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS} in your adventure secretly worships {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}, seeing its chaotic nature as true freedom from the gods' strictures. deity.name: Vaeil
deity.symbol: A serene, all-seeing eye within a perfect clock, surrounded by the Ouroboros.
entries: {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is the benevolent deity who brought order from primordial chaos and established the flow of time. He is the guardian of the timeline, ensuring that the grand design of the cosmos unfolds as it should.

While {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW} is often seen as a distant and impassive force, his influence is felt in the cycles of the seasons, the turning of the stars, and the natural progression of life and death. His followers, such as the {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS}, strive to maintain order, preserve knowledge, and protect the world from the disruptive influence of chaotic forces.

{@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}'s power is not one of direct intervention, but of subtle guidance and correction. He acts through his devoted followers to restore balance and mend the tears in the fabric of reality caused by beings like {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}. His greatest triumph was the ending of the {@adventure War of Sundering|MTW|war-of-sundering}, which he accomplished by resetting time, an act that fractured a part of his soul, creating the entity known as {@creature Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil|MTW|Vaelithra}.

deity.name: Xy'loth
deity.symbol: A stylized serpent intertwined with a shattered clock, its head poised to strike the center.
entries: {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the primordial chaos that exists outside of time. It is not a being of flesh and blood but a malevolent force that seeks to unravel the orderly fabric of the multiverse, which was woven by {@deity Vaeil|The Primordials|MTW}.

Unlike other demons who seek power or conquest, {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}'s sole purpose is the ultimate unmaking of all things, returning them to the chaotic void from which it came. Its influence is insidious, working through whispers and subversion rather than brute force.

{@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth} is the master of lies, twisting the faith of mortals, and turning order against itself. The {@creature Acolyte of Silver Light|MTW-VS} in your adventure secretly worships {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}, seeing its chaotic nature as true freedom from the gods' strictures. They believe that by bringing about the "{@adventure Ruin of Silver Light|MTW-VS|ruin-of-silver-light}," they are paving the way for {@creature Xy'loth, the Archdemon|MTW|Xyloth}'s ultimate victory and the final liberation of all creation into pure chaos.

entries.name: White Dragons
entries: {@i Dragons of Cold and Cruelty}

Among the most primal chromatic dragons, white dragons prioritize survival over all. Life is harsh and uncertain in the arctic expanses, glacial heights, and frozen seas where these dragons dwell. White dragons fiercely protect their territories, scouring the frigid regions for food and evidence of trespassers. Most white dragons ignore the plots of smaller creatures and other dragons, concerning themselves only with their own survival.

White dragons create lairs to defend themselves from other deadly arctic creatures and from dangerous natural conditions. Within these shelters, white dragons hoard testaments to their superiority, such as monstrous skulls, the gear of defeated rivals, and curiosities that capture their interest. To protect such treasure, white dragons coax ice to form over their hoards or sink their wealth in frigid pools. For white dragons, each piece of treasure embodies a victory—the details of which inflate as these dragons age.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2}, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The scout makes two attacks, using Shortsword and Longbow in any combination.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 4}, range 150/600 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) Piercing damage.
Scouts are keen archers and acutely aware of their surroundings. They often know several regions particularly well and are familiar with local creatures, landmarks, and perils.

entries.name: Scouts
entries: {@i Watchers and Wanderers}
Scouts are warriors of the wilderness, trained in hunting and tracking. They might be explorers or trappers, or they could perform more martial roles as archers, bounty hunters, or outriders.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bandit makes two attacks, using Scimitar and Pistol in any combination.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Pistol
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 5}, range 30/90 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) Piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: {@actTrigger} The bandit is hit by a melee attack roll while holding a weapon. {@actResponse} The bandit adds 2 to its AC against that attack, possibly causing it to miss.
Bandit captains command gangs of scoundrels and conduct straightforward heists. Others serve as guards and muscle for more influential criminals.

entries.name: Bandits
entries: {@i Criminals and Scoundrels}

Bandits use the threat of violence to take what they want. Such criminals include gang members, desperadoes, and lawless mercenaries. Yet not all bandits are motivated by greed. Some are driven to lives of crime by unjust laws, desperation, or the threats of merciless leaders.
Roll on or choose a result from the Bandit Motivations table to determine the circumstances behind a bandit's crimes.
I am he who rules the world, don't you know? One little piece at a time.

entries.caption: Bandit Motivations
rows: Is an ex-soldier who was discarded by their nation and now takes what they were promised.
Is in a gang that views nonmembers as foes.
Secretly works for a government or a regional ruler to sow chaos.
Takes what they need to survive.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Maw makes two attacks: one with its Bite and one with its Claw.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become Frightened of the Maw until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be grappled (escape DC 15).

trait.name: Festering Feast
entries: The Abyssal Maw regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it is in an area of corruption or within 5 feet of a grappled or frightened creature.

monster.name: Vaeil, The God of Time
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Vaeil makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Chronal Shift (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Vaeil can reroll a saving throw it just failed. It must use the new roll. This can be used to counter an effect that would reduce its Legendary Resistance.

legendary.name: Divine Strike (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Vaeil makes one melee weapon attack. On a hit, the target takes an additional 27 ({@damage 5d10}) radiant damage.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Vaeil's spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 26}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
At will: {@spell command}, {@spell time ravage|MTW}
3/day each: {@spell banishment}, {@spell divine word}
1/day each: {@spell foresight}, {@spell prismatic wall}

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (5/Day)
entries: If Vaeil fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Time Reversal
entries: If Vaeil would be reduced to 0 hit points, his current hit point total instead resets to 400 hit points, he recharges all his abilities, and he regains any expended uses of Legendary Resistance.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Vaeil makes two melee attacks with its radiant fists.

action.name: Radiant Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: 15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Temporal Warp
entries: Vaeil chooses a point within 120 feet of him. A 30-foot-radius sphere centered on that point becomes a zone of temporal distortion until the start of his next turn. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature's speed is halved, and it can't take reactions. On a successful save, the creature's speed is halved. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

monster.name: Vaelithra, Fragment of Vaeil
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks

trait.name: Change Shape
entries: Vaelithra can use her action to polymorph into a Medium humanoid she has seen, or back into her true form. Her statistics, other than her size, are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.

In her humanoid form, she appears as a striking but unassuming human woman with silver-streaked hair and eyes that occasionally flicker with an inner light. This form is her preferred way to interact with mortals, as it helps her remain inconspicuous while still maintaining an air of otherworldly grace.

trait.name: Fragmented Divinity
entries: As a shard of Vaeil, Vaelithra wields divine power but cannot fully control it. Whenever she rolls a natural 1 on an attack roll, saving throw, or ability check, time shatters momentarily. Each creature within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: Vaelithra's spellcasting ability is Charisma spell save {@dc 21}. She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
At will: {@spell hold person}, {@spell slow}, {@spell counterspell}
3/day each: {@spell banishment}, {@spell greater restoration}, {@spell wall of force}
1/day each: {@spell time stop}, {@spell foresight}

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Vaelithra fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Vaelithra makes two attacks with her Chronal Strike.

action.name: Chronal Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) force damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage. On a hit, the target must succeed on a DC 21 Wisdom saving throw or lose its reaction until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Temporal Distortion
entries: Vaelithra bends the flow of time in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point she can see within 120 feet. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 21 Wisdom saving throw or be either aged (disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws) or slowed (as the {@spell slow} spell) for 1 minute. The effect ends early if Vaelithra loses concentration (as if concentrating on a spell).

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Vaelithra makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Warp Step
entries: Vaelithra teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space she can see.

legendary.name: Chronal Glimpse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Vaelithra forces a creature she can see within 30 feet to reroll an attack roll, saving throw, or ability check it just made. The creature must use the new roll.

monster.name: Xy'loth, the Archdemon
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks

legendary.name: Shattering Strike (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Xy'loth makes one melee weapon attack. On a hit, the target must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw or have one nonmagical item it is carrying destroyed.

legendary.name: Corrupting Gaze (Costs 1 Action)
entries: Xy'loth targets one creature he can see within 60 feet of him. The target must succeed on a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) psychic damage and become poisoned until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Chaotic Aura
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of Xy'loth must succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw or become confused for 1 minute. A confused creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. While confused, a creature can't take reactions and must roll a {@dice d10} at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior. On a 1-4, it does nothing. On a 5-6, it makes a melee attack against a random target. On a 7-8, it makes a ranged attack against a random target. On a 9-10, it does nothing.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If Xy'loth fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Xy'loth makes three melee attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: 19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) piercing damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) slashing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.

monsterFluff.name: Acolyte of Silver Light
entries: A fellow of loyal servant to the God of Time and keper of the Archive, {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}, under the guidance of the Priest of Silver Light ranks, they submit to {@deity Vaeil|the primordials|MTW}.
Their attire is consist of a grey light robe, they always carry a dagger on their person

monsterFluff.name: High Priest of Silver Light
entries: The hiehest rank of the Silver Light cultist, their influence alone enough to move the acolytes at once.
They're a 5th level {@i spellcaster}

monsterFluff.name: Priest of Silver Light
entries: One of the high ranks of the Silver Light cultist, their influence alone enough to move the acolytes at once.
They're a 5th level {@i spellcaster}

monsterFluff.name: The Abyssal Maw
entries: An abomination and the loyal pet of {@deity Xy'loth|demon lords|MTW}

spell.name: Time Ravage
entries: You unleash a wave of temporal energy at a creature you can see within range. The target must make a {@dc 26} Constitution saving throw, taking 10d10 force damage and aging 10 years on a failed save, or half as much damage and aging 5 years on a successful one.

If the aging effect would cause the target to die of old age, the target dies instantly and turns to dust. Otherwise, the aging effect is permanent and cannot be reversed by any means short of a {@spell wish} spell.
